app.appName: Technical Theatre, Lighting, Sound and Stage
Technical Theatre, Lighting, Sound and Stage
Technical Theatre, Lighting, Sound and Stage
Technical Theatre, Lighting, Sound and Stage

Technical Theatre, Lighting, Sound and Stage

Wood and Timber Processing and Merchants Industry
Wood and Timber Processing and Merchants Industry

app.stnOverview: Designing, installing, maintaining and supporting communication networks within an organisation or between organisations.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have one of the following:
* A levels * a level 3 apprenticeship or other relevant qualification * relevant experience or an aptitude test with a focus on functional maths
app.stnLearn: * principles of networking, protocols and associated technologies * using diagnostic tools to find the causes of system failure * architecture of a typical business IT system * designing simple networks from specification and optimising performance * installing and configuring network parts, including switches, routers and firewalls * undertaking system upgrades and integrating software into an existing network * interpreting written requirements and technical specifications * logging and responding to network service calls
app.stnQual:
Apprentices must achieve an internationally recognised vendor or professional qualification, selected by the employer.
Apprentices must achieve level 2 in English and maths by the end of their apprenticeship, if they haven’t already done so.
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship is recognised for entry onto the register of IT technicians at Skills Framework for the Information Age (SFIA) level 3.

app.stnOverview: Building and testing simple, high-quality code for software.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have one of the following:
* A levels * a level 3 apprenticeship or other relevant qualification * relevant experience or an aptitude test with a focus on functional maths
app.stnLearn: * software development lifecycle and methodologies * writing code in at least 1 language and creating a user interface for at least 1 channel * linking code to databases * problem solving, testing code and analysing results to correct errors * design: creating data models and software designs * analysis: understanding and creating basic analysis artefacts * deployment: building, managing and deploying code into enterprise environments * applying maths (algorithms, logic and data structures) in software development
app.stnQual: Apprentices must achieve level 2 in English and maths by the end of their apprenticeship, if they haven’t already done so.
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship is recognised for entry onto the register of IT technicians at Skills Framework for the Information Age (SFIA) level 3.

app.stnOverview: Using engineering data and relevant equipment to assemble aircraft systems, testing and adjusting systems to ensure they meet specifications.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 4 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * theory of flight, aerodynamics and aircraft manufacturing processes * electrical, electronic and fluid power theory * structure, properties and characteristics of materials used in building aircraft * reading and interpreting engineering drawings and specifications * designing efficient and cost-effective manufacturing processes * assembly and disassembly of aero components, sub-assemblies and whole systems * safe selection and use of specialist equipment * assembly, sealing and jointing techniques
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg:
The apprenticeship is recognised at ‘engineering technician’ level by:
*the Institution of Engineering and Technology * the Royal Aeronautical Society * the Institution of Mechanical engineers

app.stnOverview: Ensuring that plant and equipment perform to required standards in manufacturing environments.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 4 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * how to use and interpret a range of engineering data sources and supporting documentation * using lean techniques to improve efficiency and effectiveness * how to support installation, testing and commissioning of a wide range of equipment * complex fault diagnosis and repair on high technology engineered systems * how to minimise machinery downtime by carrying out preventative planned maintenance * confirmation testing and subsequent smooth handover of equipment and plant * knowledge from a range of academic disciplines, including mathematics and engineering
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: Completion of this apprenticeship standard will be recognized by the relevant professional institutions as evidence required for engineeering technician (EngTech) registration through a professional review.

app.stnOverview: Installing, maintaining and repairing electrical systems in industrial, commercial and domestic environments.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * terminating and connecting conductors, cables and cords in electrical systems * preparing and installing wiring systems and electrotechnical equipment * inspecting, testing, commissioning and certifying of eletrotechnical equipment * diagnosing and correcting electrical faults * selecting equipment and planning its instillation * maintaining electrotechnical systems and equipment
app.stnQual: * Level 3 Electrotechnical Qualification (installation or maintenance) * Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: At the end of the apprenticeship, apprentices can register as en engineering technician (Eng Tech) with the Engineering Council.

app.stnOverview: Constructing, maintaining and repairing the UK’s electrical power network, providing a safe and reliable supply of electricity to the country.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have at least 3 GCSEs at grades A to C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * electrical testing and how to respond to the results of tests * electrical theories applicable to building and maintaining electrical power networks * electrical/mechanical principles and their use in work processes * using maths calculations in power engineering * legislation and regulation * using specialist tools and equipment * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: overhead lines, underground cables, substation fitting
app.stnQual: Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be able to register as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) with the Institution of Engineering and Technology.

app.stnOverview: Providing financial products and services to customers, helping them achieve their business goals.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have A levels or other relevant level 3 qualifications. Employers may also consider relevant prior experience.
app.stnLearn: * ethical standards * product knowledge * risk and governance * market awareness * customer relationships * financial analysis * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: corporate, retail, wealth
app.stnQual:
Professional qualifications for this apprenticeship depend on the level of experience in the sector and the parts of the bank the apprentice works in. You can find more details in the apprenticeship standard.
Apprentices without level 2 English and maths must achieve this standard before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg:
Depending on their specialism, successful apprentices will be able to apply for registration with the following organisations:
* retail banking: Chartered Banker Institute, Institute of Financial Services * wealth: Chartered Banker Institute, Institute of Financial Services, Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment, Chartered Insurance Institute * corporate banking: Chartered Banker Institute, Institute of Financial Services, Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) Institute

app.stnOverview: Providing administrative support to a financial organisation, to provide a high quality and compliant service.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 1 of the following:
* level 2 maths and English, ideally as part of 5 GCSEs grades A to C * equivalent qualifications or prior experience
app.stnLearn: * the financial services market * the financial services regulatory framework * ethics and key principles of the financial advice process * the purpose and technical content of financial services products and services * systems and processes required to carry out the role of financial services administrator
app.stnQual:
Apprentices will take a range of professional qualifications, as set out in the apprenticeship standard.
Candidates who don’t have English and maths at grace C or above (or equivalent) will have to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship provides the first step on the pathway to professional membership of the Chartered Insurance Institute, Institute of Financial Services and the Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment.

app.stnOverview: Assuring that manufacturing runs smoothly in areas such as site maintenance.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and a science, technology or engineering related subject * A levels at grade C or above in a maths-based subject and a science, technology, engineering or another maths-related subject (or 90+ credits in an engineering BTEC at level 3)
app.stnLearn: * using and interpreting engineering data * installation, testing and commissioning of equipment and fault diagnosis and repair * maintaining mechanical, fluid and pneumatic power equipment * maintaining electrical, electronic and process control equipment * minimising machinery downtime by carrying out preventative planned maintenance * leading complex maintenance or technical support activities * carrying out testing and calibration of instrumentation control equipment * academic knowledge from a relevant degree
app.stnQual: BSc (Hons) or BEng (Hons) in Engineering
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Supporting the manufacturing of new products by brining the product to life and resolving manufacturing problems.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and a science, technology or engineering related subject * A levels at grade C or above in a maths-based subject and a science, technology, engineering or another maths-related subject (or 90+ credits in an engineering BTEC at level 3)
app.stnLearn: * producing parts using hand fitting techniques * producing electrical or electronic drawings using a computer aided design (CAD) system * preparing and using general and specialist machines and equipment * wiring and testing electrical equipment, and maintaining electrical equipment and systems * assembling and testing electronic circuits * producing engineering plans * engineering project management and working with engineering specifications and briefs * electrical/electronic product manufacturing and testing * academic knowledge from an engineering degree
app.stnQual: BSc (Hons) or BEng (Hons) in Engineering
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Helping take products from design to manufacture, ensuring that they are launched on time, on cost and to the right quality.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and a science, technology or engineering related subject * A levels at grade C or above in a maths-based subject and a science, technology, engineering or another maths-related subject (or 90+ credits in an engineering BTEC at level 3)
app.stnLearn: * producing parts using hand fitting, fabrication and joining techniques * producing drawings using a computer aided design (CAD) system * preparing and using general and specialist machines and equipment * preparing and providing computer numeric control programmes (programmes that control machinery) * using computer software packages to help with engineering activities * producing assemblies using a wide range of materials and techniques * engineering project management, securing resources and managing budgets * implementing, monitoring and evaluating engineering processes
app.stnQual: BSc (Hons) or BEng (Hons) in Engineering
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Using engineering techniques to bring new products to life or redesign existing products.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and a science, technology or engineering related subject * A levels at grade C or above in a maths-based subject and a science, technology, engineering or another maths-related subject (or 90+ credits in an engineering BTEC at level 3)
An apprenticeship as a product design and development technician also provides a potential preparation route for this standard.
app.stnLearn: * Interpreting, evaluating and using engineering data * producing parts using hand fitting techniques and producing mechanical assemblies * producing electrical or electronic drawings using a computer aided design (CAD) system * using general and specialist equipment, including mechanical, electrical and electronic devices and equipment * managing and controlling product design change * engineering project management * creating design briefs, presenting and discussing technical proposals * academic knowledge from an engineering degree
app.stnQual: BSc (Hons) or BEng (Hons) in Engineering
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Helping engineers create and modify products, from early concept feasibility, design and development stages to final preparation for launch.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 4 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * using and interpreting engineering data * producing parts and prototypes using hand fitting techniques * using general and specialist equipment * producing assemblies and rigs using a range of materials and techniques * applying electrical and electronic principles to products and equipment * identifying, diagnosing and rectifying design problems * using the latest advanced manufacturing technologies * academic knowledge from guided learning
app.stnQual: Employers who recruit candidates without English and maths GCSE grade C (or Functional Skills level 2) or above must ensure that the candidate achieves this level before completion of the apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: None
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * working safely in a laboratory * following quality procedures * regulatory requirements * technical skills to fulfil their role * producing, analysing and interpreting data, and applying statistical techniques * communicating scientific information appropriately * using appropriate scientific methods to identify the causes of problems and produce solutions
app.stnQual:
Apprentices must complete a level 3 or 4 qualification in a science or technology discipline relevant to their occupation and recognised for registration as a registered science technician (RSciTech).
Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship is recognised by the relevant professional organisations at RSciTech level.

app.stnOverview: Operating the systems and equipment involved in the production of products.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * starting, operating and shutting down a manufacturing batch or continuous process * working safely in a science manufacturing environment * quality procedures and standards * complying with regulations * controlling and monitoring a process or plant and equipment * applying relevant science and technology
app.stnQual:
A level 3 or 4 qualification in science or technology that is relevant to their occupation and recognised for registration as a registered science technician (RSciTech) or engineering technician (EngTech).
Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths (or equivalent) will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship is recognised by the relevant professional organisations at RSciTech and EngTech levels.

app.stnOverview: Maintaining machinery and equipment in the food and drinks industry, finding and resolving faults, to optimise production levels.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 4 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * food processing and manufacturing methods * routine mechanical maintenance and producing replacement parts, using manual and machine processes * welding stainless steel and other materials used in food production equipment * regulatory requirements * materials science, including the key features of raw materials and how they are used in food production * principles of electrical systems * utilities, including energy management and pollution control * for apprentices specialising as multi-skilled maintenance engineers: instrumentation and process control systems, electrical maintenance and maintenance of programmable control systems
app.stnQual: Apprentices who don’t have level 2 (or equivalent) in English and maths will need to achieve this level before they complete their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will satisfy the requirements for professional registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) as defined by the UK Standard for Professional Engineering Competence.

app.stnOverview: Helping colleagues to build mathematical models to make financial predications for clients.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * actuarial techniques used in the pensions, insurance or investment industry * actuarial concepts, models and approaches * actuarial software, technology and tools * structure of the financial services market, the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries and the regulatory environment
app.stnQual: Apprentices will be assessed by one of the following: * modules 0 (entry exam) and 1 (finance and financial mathematics), Institute and Faculty of Actuaries’ Certified Actuarial Analyst qualification * core technical module (CT1: financial mathematics), Institute and Faculty of Actuaries’ Fellowship qualification Apprentices will also have to pass the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries’ online professional awareness test.
app.stnReg: Provides professional membership of the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries.

app.stnOverview: Designing, manufacturing, modifying and repairing custom-made dental appliances.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have A levels or existing relevant level 3 qualifications (or relevant prior experience).
app.stnLearn: * oral anatomy * how dental devises restore functionality and prevent oral disease * procedures used in the design and manufacture of custom made devices * selecting materials for use in dental devices * advising the prescribing dentist on appropriate dental devices * how devices are made, including digital manufacturing procedures * implants and attachments * decontamination and infection control
app.stnQual: Employers who recruit candidates without English and maths GCSE at grade C or above (or equivalent) must ensure that candidates achieve this standard before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: On completion, apprentices can apply to register with the General Dental Council as a dental technician.

app.stnOverview: Assisting dental technicians, who design, make, modify and repair custom made dental devices.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have a minimum of 4 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent), including English and maths.
app.stnLearn: * oral anatomy * material selection and uses * recognising manufacturing requirements and meeting clinical standards for custom made dental devices * helping technicians with the early stages of making dental devices * decontamination and infection control
app.stnQual: Employers who recruit candidates without English and maths GCSE at grade C or above (or equivalent) must ensure that candidates achieve this standard before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: On completion of this apprenticeship, the apprentice can start a higher apprenticeship. People who complete the higher apprenticeship can register with the General Dental Council as a qualified dental technician.

app.stnOverview: Managing all non-clinical aspects of a dental surgery, leading the practice team and achieving excellent patient care and cost efficiency.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* GCSE grade C or above (or equivalent) in English and Maths * A levels or other level 3 qualifications
Prior relevant experience may also be considered as suitable.
app.stnLearn: * human resources * patient care * knowledge of clinical teams, dental diseases and terminology, and clinical audits * marketing of the dental practice * regulation and quality assurance * finance * NHS and private sector service delivery requirements * leadership and management skills

app.stnOverview: Caring for the overall appearance of a golf course, maintaining a good quality playing surface and ensuring a challenging and enjoyable experience for golfers.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have at least 5 GCSEs at grades A to D (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * preparing the golf course for play * preparing and using specialist equipment to maintain and renovate turf surfaces * applying turf treatments and controlling weeds, fungal diseases, pests and turf disorders * maintaining and renovating bunkers * maintaining drainage and irrigation systems * how to identify plants and trees * soil and plant biology * basic computer skills
app.stnQual: Apprentices who don’t have level 1 (or equivalent) in English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: At the start of the apprenticeship the apprentice will be registered with the British and International Golf Greenkeepers Association (BIGGA). At the end of the apprenticeship, successful apprentices will be eligible to join BIGGA as a full member and become an accredited greenkeeper.

app.stnOverview: Creating news items using a combination of words, pictures and moving images.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * identifying and researching stories * building a range of reliable contacts and audiences, including via social media * create quality stories while working in an ethical manner * creating content for digital platforms * working to tight deadlines * accurately taking notes * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: print, TV and radio, PR and corporate communications
app.stnQual:
This apprenticeship includes the National Council for the Training of Journalists Level 3 Diploma in Journalism.
Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.

app.stnOverview: Ensuring that a buildings are in a safe working condition.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have maths and English at level 1.
app.stnLearn: * health and safety compliance * working safely at heights * carrying out repairs to a building * maintaining plumbing and drainage systems * maintaining electrical distribution in a building * maintaining plant, safety systems and equipment * energy, environment and sustainability practices * maintaining the outside of a building * using specialist tools and equipment to carry out repairs
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: Apprentices will have associate membership of the British Institute of Facilities Management during their apprenticeship.

app.stnOverview: Creating digital and technology solutions that enable businesses to develop new products and services and increase productivity.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 1 of the following:
* 3 A levels (including maths) or equivalent * other relevant qualifications or experience
app.stnLearn: * analysing a business domain, highlighting issues and identifying opportunities for improvement * analysing business and technical requirements and selecting appropriate technology solutions * using data modelling techniques and standard database management systems * carrying out risk assessments for IT systems and proposing a resolution to threats * business organisation * computer and network infrastructure * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: software engineer, IT consultant, business analyst, cyber security analyst, data analyst, network engineer
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Safely installing, exchanging and maintaining smart meters, explaining to customers how they work and how to use energy more efficiently.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have at least 2 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including English and maths. Employers will also carry out a recognised background check.
app.stnLearn: * health, safety and environmental legislation and regulation * gas and electrical testing and installation * installing, replacing, commissioning, decommissioning and maintaining smart meters and related equipment * using specialist tools and equipment * applying electrical/mechanical principles in work processes and procedures * knowledge of how smart meter systems work and energy efficiency principles
app.stnQual:
Apprentices must achieve registration on the Gas Safe Register and Meter Operators Code of Practice Agreement (MOCoPA).
Apprentices without level 1 English and maths will need to achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices can apply for membership with the Institution of Gas Engineers and Managers (IGEM) and the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET).

app.stnOverview: Carrying out reacting and routine maintenance on water process equipment, working on water supply and treatment, water networks and leakage, sewerage and wastewater.
app.stnEntry: Candidates will usually have at least 3 GCSEs at grades A to C (or equivalent), including maths and English.
app.stnLearn: * maintenance practices, processes and procedures, covering a range of waste and water systems, plant and equipment * water industry operations in water and waste water treatment, water and sewerage network operations * how to use specialist equipment and IT systems * how to find and respond to faults in systems and equipment * carrying out risk assessments
app.stnQual: Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be eligible for engineering technician (Eng Tech) (or equivalent) professional registration.

app.stnOverview: Helping customers in banks and building societies or the broader financial services sector.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * the role of banking in the financial services sector * regulatory and legal compliance * products and services that their company offers to customers * systems and processes needed to do their job, including IT tools and digital banking platforms * customer service
app.stnQual: None specified. The assessment plan suggests qualifications that employers can use to ensure that apprentices have strong technical knowledge.
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship puts the apprentice on the pathway towards professional membership of the Chartered Banker Institute, the Institute of Financial Services or the Chartered Insurance institute (depending on which qualifications are taken).

app.stnOverview: Providing operational and administrative support in investment management teams.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * purpose and structure of the financial services industry * legal, regulatory and corporate risk obligations * systems, tools and processes that are required to carry out their role * client service and relationships
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship puts the apprentice on the pathway towards professional membership of the Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment.

app.stnOverview: Carrying out investment transactions on behalf of individuals or organisations.
app.stnEntry: None specified.
app.stnLearn: * the structure of the financial services industry, the purpose of markets and the process of investing * financial sector regulation and compliance * technical, investment and settlement characteristics of the main investment products * IT skills, systems and processes needed to carry out their role * client service and relationships
app.stnQual:
Apprentices will take 1 of the following qualifications, chosen by the employer:
* Investment Operations Certificate, Certificate in Investment Management, Investment Advice Diploma, Managing Operation Risk in Financial Institutions (Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment) * Investment Management Certificate (CFA Institute)
app.stnReg: Completion of the one of the qualifications listed above will enable apprentices to apply to the relevant professional organization.

app.stnOverview: Supporting customers in banks or building societies (or the broader financial services sector), working at a senor level.
app.stnEntry: None specified.
app.stnLearn: * the role of their organisation in the financial services sector * regulatory and legal compliance * products and services that their company offers to customers * customer relationship management * problem solving * for apprentices who manage a team: team leadership and development
app.stnQual:
Apprentices will take a qualification (chosen by the employer) from one of the following organisations:
* Chartered Banker Institute * Chartered Insurance Institute * Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment * Institute of Financial Services
app.stnReg:
Depending on the qualification they take, apprentices can apply for professional membership of:
* Chartered Banker Institute * Institute of Financial Services * Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment * Chartered Insurance Institute

app.stnOverview: Providing information on pensions schemes an organisation’s employees or clients.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * structure of workplace pension schemes and the different roles involved in running a scheme * regulatory and legislative environment for workplace pensions * business awareness * systems and processes needed to carry out their role * client service and relationships * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: workplace pensions administration, workplace pensions consultancy
app.stnQual:
The apprenticeship standard includes a range of possible qualifications from the:
* Pensions Management Institute * Chartered Insurance Institute * Chartered Institute of Payroll Professionals.
Employers will choose 1 or more qualifications for apprentices to study.
app.stnReg: Depending on the qualifications they achieve, apprentices will be able to apply for professional membership with the awarding professional organization.

app.stnOverview: Supporting teams that carry out investment transactions on behalf of individuals or organisations.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * role and structure of the financial services industry, the purpose of markets and the principles of investing * financial sector regulation and compliance * purpose and technical content of financial products supported by the apprentice’s role * client services and relationships
app.stnQual: * Investment Operations Certificate (Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment)
app.stnReg: Completion of the Investment Operations Certificate as part of this apprenticeship will enable apprentices to apply for associate member status with the Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment.

app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have maths and English at level 1.
app.stnLearn: * health and safety compliance * working safely at heights * carrying out repairs to a building * maintaining plumbing and drainage systems * maintaining electrical distribution in a building * maintaining plant, safety systems and equipment * energy, environment and sustainability practices * maintaining the outside of a building * using specialist tools and equipment to carry out repairs
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: Apprentices will have associate membership of the British Institute of Facilities Management during their apprenticeship.

app.stnOverview: Carrying out quality control and welding inspections for the nuclear industry, to ensure the safety and robustness of nuclear sites.
app.stnEntry: Set by employers. Candidates will usually have 5 GCSEs at grades A to C (or equivalent), including maths and English at grade B or above.
app.stnLearn: * material science * welding technology * welding inspection * certification * non-destructive testing techniques (checking for cracks in plant or equipment) * health and safety * business improvement
app.stnQual: The apprenticeship standard sets out a range of mandatory qualifications.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be able to register as en engineering technician (EngTech) with relevant professional organisations.

app.stnOverview: Creating aircraft components and equipment, specialising in a specific engineering discipline (eg airframe, design and stress, systems integration, support engineering or manufacturing engineering).
app.stnEntry: * academic qualifications of 240 UCAS points or above at A level standard (or equivalent) * must include maths plus at least 1 other science, technology or engineering subject * 5 GCSEs at grades A to C, including maths, English and double science (or an equivalent qualification)
app.stnLearn: * engineering process and practices * regulatory and quality requirements * analytical methods (engineering mathematics) * aeronautical sciences * material sciences * business improvement techniques * technical skills that can be applied in a range of aerospace disciplines
app.stnQual: * level 2 aerospace and aviation (foundation competence) * level 4 engineering and manufacture (development competence) * level 5 aerospace engineering (development technical knowledge) * employer stipulated level 6 Bachelor Honours degree
app.stnReg: Completion of the apprenticeship is designed to be recognised by the relevant professional engineering institutions at the appropriate level of professional registration (IEng).

app.stnOverview: Developing software to support the aerospace industry.
app.stnEntry: * academic qualifications of 240 UCAS points or above at A level standard (or equivalent) * must include maths plus at least 1 other science, technology or engineering subject * 5 GCSEs at grades A to C, including maths, English and double science (or an equivalent qualification)
app.stnLearn: * the fundamentals of software engineering * configuration management and software build processes * how to develop and apply algorithms * application of engineering operations and toolsets * engineering mathematics * systems engineering * modelling and simulation software * how to interpret engineering data * business improvement techniques
app.stnQual: * level 4 aerospace software engineering (development competence) * level 5 aerospace software engineering (development technical knowledge) * employer stipulated level 6 Bachelor Honours degree (BSc)
app.stnReg: Completion of the apprenticeship has been designed to be recognized by relevant professional engineering institutions at the appropriate level of registration (IEng).

app.stnOverview: Supporting licensed conveyancers with legal matters relating to the transfer of ownership of land or property.
app.stnEntry: None specified.
app.stnLearn: * how to provide professional support in a legal office environment * using appropriate legal methods to research, request, complete and submit legal forms * managing legal files and using client case management and accounting systems * handling client enquiries * basic knowledge of the principles of law applicable to conveyancing * professional ethics, codes of conduct and regulatory arrangements * customer service * problem solving and critical thinking
app.stnQual: Apprentices will have to complete recognised Council for Licensed Conveyancers (CLC) qualifications.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Responsible for legal matters relating to the transfer of ownership of land or property, managing client portfolios and providing conveyancing legal services.
app.stnEntry: None specified.
app.stnLearn: * how to provide legal services, including advice and guidance * assessing legal, regulatory and commercial risk * prioritising and planning appropriate actions for a business and in a client’s best interests * effectively managing dealings with other lawyers and professional third parties * managing clients and their expectations *managing legal files, case management and accounting systems * drafting and reviewing legal documents relating to property and land transactions * comprehensive knowledge of the principles of law applicable to conveyancing * professional ethics, codes of conduct and regulatory arrangements
app.stnQual: Apprentices will have to complete recognised Council for Licensed Conveyancers (CLC) qualifications.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Providing legal services to clients and colleagues.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 4 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in English language or English literature.
app.stnLearn: * business and ethics in law * commercial awareness and finance * risk and compliance * technical legal knowledge * research skills * drafting legal documentation accurately * data and file management * providing legal advice
app.stnQual: * Chartered Institute of Legal Executives (CILEx) Level 3 Professional Diploma in Law and Practice * CILEx Level 6 Professional Higher Diploma in Law and Practice
app.stnReg: Apprentices will be registered members of CILEx during their apprenticeship.

app.stnOverview: Providing legal support, including administrative tasks, carrying out research and drafting legal documents and forms.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have the following qualifications (or equivalent):
* GCSE maths and English, grade C or above * 2 A levels, grade C or above
app.stnLearn: * legal and regulatory requirements relevant to their role * carrying out research and presenting findings accurately and clearly * using precedents and draft documents, using plain and succinct language * assisting with legal matters and transactions * administrative skills * building strong relationships with clients and colleagues
app.stnQual: CILEx Level 3 Diploma in Providing Legal Services
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Progressing legal matters and transactions, applying legal knowledge and commercial judgement to produce solutions which meet clients’ needs.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. The apprenticeship standard sets out a range recommended requirements.
app.stnLearn: * ethics, professionalism and judgement * technical legal practice * working with other people * managing themselves and their work
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: The standard is based on the Solicitors Regulation Authority’s Statement of of Solicitor Competence. Achieving the apprenticeship standard will satisfy the authority’s regulatory framework for qualification as a solicitor (subject to the authority’s usual tests).

app.stnOverview: Carrying out technical and scientific activity in laboratories.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* grade C or above (or equivalent) in English and maths * A levels or existing level 3 qualifications (or equivalent)
Employers may consider previous experience as an alternative to the above qualifications.
app.stnLearn: * underlying scientific principles in laboratory based experimentation * principles of laboratory techniques and scientific experimentation * theories of advanced science and technology applicable in their role * project management * regulatory requirements * responding to customer requirements * health and safety requirements
app.stnQual: Apprentices who don’t have level 2 (or equivalent) in English or maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship. Some employers may expect qualifications at level 3 in maths.
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship is recognised by the relevant professional organisations at registered scientist (RSci) level.

app.stnOverview: Contributing to the operation of science industry plant by installing, maintaining, testing and repair of mechanical and electrical equipment.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employers. Candidates will usually have:
* grade C or above (or equivalent) in English and maths * level 2 or above (or equivalent) in STEM (science, technology, engineering and maths) subject
app.stnLearn: * working safely in a science industry environment * quality procedures and requirements * regulatory requirements * problem solving techniques * specialist equipment and engineering techniques * routine and non-routine maintenance of equipment * understanding and applying engineering drawings, specification diagrams and maintenance manuals * engineering theories and how they apply to their role
app.stnQual: Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be able to register as an engineering technician (EngTech) as defined by the UK Standard for Professional Engineering Competence (UK-SPEC).

app.stnOverview: Proving radiological monitoring services in the nuclear industry to protect people, plant and the environment from contamination.
Assisting financial advisers with researching, analysing and preparing financial reports for clients.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * structure of the financial services market, including the role of the financial adviser, the paraplanner, product providers and support services * financial services regulation and compliance * financial products and financial planning tools * systems and processes needed to carry out their role * customer service and relationships * planning and prioritising
app.stnQual: Certificate in Paraplanning from the Chartered Insurance Institute or the Institute of Financial Planning
app.stnReg:
Depending on the qualification they take, successful apprentices will be able to register as 1 of the following:
* Cert PFS (paraplanning) with the Chartered Insurance Institute * accredited parapanner with the Institute of Financial Planning

app.appName: refrigeration air conditioning and heat pump engineering technician
app.stnOverview: Planning, preparing and safely carrying out work in process, product and space cooling.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * relevant legislation, regulations and standards * principles of thermodynamics, gas laws, psychrometrics, fluid flow, electricity, properties of refrigerant fluids and lubricants * data analysis * the function and operation of system components and how they interact in a range of systems * sustainability * safe working practices * mechanical operations * applying mathematical principles to their work
app.stnQual: All apprentices must achieve a Level 2 Certificate in F Gas and ODS Regulations Category 1. Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship meets the professional standards of the Engineering Council for registration as an engineering technician (EngTech) in partnership with the Institute of Refrigeration and the Chartered Institute of Building Services Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Collecting information from site inspections to inform advice to clients on land, property or construction.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 1 of the following:
* 5 GCSEs at grace C or above (or equivalent), including maths and English * a level 2 apprenticeship in a construction or property related discipline
app.stnLearn: * the English legal system, law of contract and law of tort * key mathematical principles in data collection * economics * health and safety * sustainability * construction technology * other skills relating to 2 of the following specialisms: valuation and appraisal, building pathology, property and planning law, procurement and contracts, costing and cost planning of construction works
app.stnQual:
Apprentices will achieve a Level 3 Diploma in Surveying.
Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be able to apply to become associate members of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

app.stnOverview: Solving some of the most complex engineering challenges by organising all the information needed to understand the whole problem, exploring it and finding the most appropriate solution.
app.stnEntry: Candidates must have English and mathematics at level 2. Candidates will usually have an engineering degree or equivalent.
app.stnLearn: * identifying problems and needs, capturing and managing requirements, designing solutions, supporting the build process and validating solutions * applying appropriate lifecycles and approaches to developing systems, including their interrelated dependencies and benefits. * systems engineering management: managing complex interdependencies between different functions of large enterprises. * the defence sector, its structure, funding and functions * knowledge of particular specialist subjects and domains to meet employers’ needs
app.stnQual: Postgraduate diploma in systems engineering (120 credits at level 7) or equivalent
app.stnReg: Apprentices will achieve the standard of International Council on Systems Engineering (INCOSE) systems engineering practitioner. The apprenticeship also meets professional registration requirements for chartered engineers.

app.stnOverview: Carrying out reactive and routine maintenance on equipment to ensure safety and efficiency.
app.stnEntry:
Candidates will usually have at least 3 GCSEs at grades A to C (or equivalent), including maths and English.
For apprentices to specialise in electrical engineering or instrumentation control and automation, a GCSE grade B or above (or equivalent) in Maths is desirable.
app.stnLearn: * maintenance practices, processes and procedures in waste and water systems, plant and equipment * theories and principles that underpin the design and function of electro-mechanical and instrumentation systems and equipment * installing, maintaining, replacing and commissioning equipment and parts * identifying, diagnosing and correcting faults * planned, reactive and predictive maintenance processes * using specialist equipment to create, repair and modify parts and apparatus * reading, understanding and interpreting computer data and displays * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: electrical, mechanical, instrumentation control and automation
app.stnQual: Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be eligible for engineering technician (Eng Tech) (or equivalent) professional registration.

app.stnOverview: Using specialist skills to cut, prepare, package and present meat products to the standards required of a business and customers.
app.stnEntry: None specified.
app.stnLearn: * principles of butchery, waste minimisation and meat and poultry species * the values, traditions, culture and regulation of the meat sector * craft and knife skills * cold storage, stock control and safe movement of meat * health and food safety * methods for weighing products, controlling temperature, and packing and presenting meat * how to use specialist machinery
app.stnQual: * Qualifications and Credit Framwork (QCF) Level 2 Award in Food Safety * QCF Level 2 Award in Health and Safety in the Food Supply Chain * QCF Level 2 Award in Knife Skills
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be eligible to register at the appropriate level with the Institute of Meat.

app.appName: Aerospace Manufacturing, Electrical, Mechanical and Systems Fitter
app.stnOverview: Assembling, installing and testing electrical, mechanical and electromechanical equipment in aircraft.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 4 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including mathematics, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * aviation and manufacturing theories and processes * the structure, properties and characteristics of materials used in aircraft construction * assembly and disassembly of aero components, sub-assemblies and whole systems * reading and interpreting engineering data * designing and maintaining processes to improve efficiency and cost-effectiveness * using a range of measuring, testing, diagnostic tools, rigs and equipment * installing lighting, power supplies, engine control and instrumentation systems * sealing and jointing techniques
app.stnQual: * English and maths at grade C or above * level 2 aerospace and aviation (foundation competence) * level 2 aerospace and aviation (foundation technical knowledge) * level 3 aerospace and aviation (development competence) * level 3 aerospace and aviation (development technical knowledge)
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship standard has been designed to be recognised by relevant professional engineering institutions at engineering technician (EngTech) level.

app.stnOverview: Building, maintaining and repairing parts fro the country’s gas network, to provide a reliable supply of gas to domestic, commercial and industrial users.
app.stnEntry: Candidates will usually have at least 3 GCSEs at grades A to C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * carrying out risk assessments * health and safety requirements * following engineering instructions and procedures * installing, testing, purging and commissioning gas equipment * using specialist tools and equipment * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: emergency response, network maintenance (electrical and instrumentation), network maintenance (pressure management)
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be eligible for registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) with the Institution of Gas Engineers and Managers (IGEM).

app.stnOverview: Building, maintaining and repairing the country’s gas network infrastructure to provide a reliable supply of gas to domestic, commercial and industrial users.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have at least 3 GCSEs at grades A to C (or equivalent), including maths and English.
app.stnLearn: * installing, testing, purging and commissioning equipment and network infrastructure * carrying out repairs * legislation and codes of practice relevant to the position * theory and principles behind the design and function of gas equipment and systems * using gas detection equipment to ensure a safe environment * health and safety regulations and requirements * team leadership * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: service laying, main laying
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.appName: Motor Vehicle Service and Maintenance Technician
app.stnOverview: Servicing and repairing light vehicles such as cars and vans, working on al the systems found in the vehicle.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * the basics of vehicle technologies and emerging technologies * types and characteristics of light vehicles * diagnostic principles and logical problem-solving techniques * basic tasks common to all procedures * how to maintain a safe and efficient workshop * using specialist equipment * servicing and maintaining a vehicle without supervision * investigating vehicle faults and identifying causes * removing, repairing and replacing parts in line with manufacturer’s standards
app.stnQual:
Apprentices must get a qualification that meets the EU’s 2014 F-gas regulation.
Employers who recruit candidates without English and maths GCSE grade C (or Functional Skills level 2) or above must ensure that the candidate achieves this level before completion of the apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Supporting the sale and renewal of insurance products.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * the structure of the insurance market, insurance law, products and services * risk and regulation in the insurance sector * developing strong relationships with clients and colleagues * processes required to carry out their role * commercial awareness
app.stnQual: Apprentices will study for either the Certificate in Insurance (CII) or the Certificate in Claims Handling (Cert CILA).
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship provides professional membership of the Chartered Insurance Institute and the Institute of Loss Adjustors.

app.stnOverview: Assisting other dental health professionals, providing chair side support and a high level of patient care.
app.stnEntry: None specified.
app.stnLearn: * oral anatomy and physiology, respiratory and circulatory systems * how infectious diseases are transmitted and prevented * dental materials, equipment and resources * how to deal with medical emergencies * legislative compliance and regulatory requirements * clinical skills * health promotion * patient care and management
app.stnQual: A qualification that has been approved by the General Dental Council as meeting the requirements for entry to the professional register.
app.stnReg: On completion, apprentices can register with the General Dental Council as a qualified dental nurse.

app.stnOverview: Giving clients advice on appropriate mortgages and related protection products such as life insurance or sickness and unemployment insurance.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * structure of the financial services industry and their role within it * financial services legal and regulatory requirements * purpose and technical content of financial products that they provide advice on * systems and processes needed to carry out their role * customer service and relationships
app.stnQual:
Apprentices will take 1 of the following qualifications:
* Certificate in Mortgage Advice and Practice (Institute of Financial Services) * Certificate in Mortgage Advice (Chartered Insurance Institute) * Mortgage Advice and Practice Certificate (Chartered Banker Institute)
Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be able to register with the professional organisation that awards their qualification.

app.stnOverview: Specialising in an area of business within the insurance sector, for example broking, client management or underwriting.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * structure of the insurance market and the products available within it * risk and regulation in the insurance sector * developing strong relationships with clients and colleagues * processes and procedures needed to carry out their role * commercial awareness
app.stnQual: Apprentices will study for diploma level qualifications from either the Chartered Insurance Institute or the Chartered Institute of Loss Adjusters.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices can apply for registration with the professional organisation that awarded their qualification.

app.stnOverview: Providing administrative support to the housing/property team in estate agent offices.
app.stnEntry: None specified.
app.stnLearn: * legislation and regulation in the property management sector * the organisation’s business plan, policies, organisation values and range of services it offers * customer service, including how to respond to vulnerable customers * quality standards * administrative skills * collecting and sharing information * decision-making and time management skills * using IT equipment and software
app.stnQual: Apprentices without level 1 English and maths will need to achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship. They will also need to take the tests for level 2.
app.stnReg:
At the end of the apprenticeship, apprentices will be able to join the:
* Chartered Institute of Housing at member level * Association of Residential Letting Agents at associate grade or member grade * Institute of Residential Property Management at foundation level or associate level

app.stnOverview: Creating and sustaining successful tenancies in the private and social rented housing sectors.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * legislation and regulation in the property management sector * principles, policies and values of the organisation they work for * how to resolve defects, common problems, health and safety issues and repairs * customer service * housing services, including allocations, lettings, tenancy sustainment, and financial and social inclusion * responding to the needs of vulnerable customers * influencing and negotiating skills * decision-making skills
app.stnQual: Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg:
Successful apprentices will be able to join the:
* Chartered Institute of Housing at associate level * Association of Residential Letting Agents at associate level

app.stnOverview: Managing housing or property related services, leading a team and taking responsibility for the cost effectiveness and efficiency of their business area.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * legislation and regulation in the property management sector * business planning, financial and risk management, organisational performance management systems * customer relationships and stakeholder management * providing advice on housing services such as repair and maintenance * financial management * people management * decision-making and prioritising * using IT equipment and software
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg:
Successful apprentices will be able to join the:
* Chartered Institute of Housing at member level * Association of Residential Letting Agents at member grade or fellow member grade * Institute of Residential Property Management at member level

app.stnOverview: Using specialist methods to detect cracks and other imperfections in manufactured components, including those that have been in service for a period of time.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer, but apprentices must have good aided or unaided eyesight and fitness.
Candidates will usually have at least 3 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including English and maths.
app.stnLearn: * relevant maths, including numerical and data analysis * 3 non-destructive testing methods, including gathering contextual information before testing * formula-based engineering and current technologies * using specialist materials, tools, equipment and technology * interpreting engineering or computer-aided design (CAD) drawings * applying the results of non-destructive testing to produce solutions * health and safety requirements * project management and supervising other staff
app.stnQual:
Apprentices must achieve non-destructive testing level 2 certification in 3 methods, in accordance with national and international standards.
Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices can register with the Engineering Council at engineering technician (EngTech) level.

app.stnOverview: Helping organisations meet sustainability commitments by reducing energy consumption and reducing costs.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have at least 3 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent), including English and maths.
app.stnLearn: * theory and practices relating to energy, energy efficiency and energy loss assessment * energy performance, water measurement and verification of measured data * the economics of energy consumption * energy legislation, regulation and policy environments * collecting, recording and analysing data from energy meters and understanding manufacturers’ installation and maintenance requirements * estimating energy from solid or liquid fuels that aren’t metered * energy tariffs * improving energy management and how this contributes to an organisation’s broader strategies
app.stnQual: Apprentices without English or Maths at grade C or above (or equivalent) must achieve this before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be eligible for registration as a recognised energy manager with the Energy Managers Association (EMA) and a technician member with the Technician Member Energy Institute.

app.stnOverview: Maintaining a range of machinery, plant and equipment in one sectors such as agriculture, forestry and horticulture.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have GCSE English and maths at grade C (or equivalent) and a basic understanding of information and communication technology (ICT).
app.stnLearn: * environmental, safe working and legal requirements * selecting and using specialist tools and equipment * thermally and chemically joining metals and components * principles of land-based engine machinery, plant and equipment * service, maintenance and repair principles and practices * interpreting technical data
app.stnQual: * Level 2 Diploma in Land-based Engineering * Certificate in Emergency First Aid * Certificate in Abrasive Wheels
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Providing advanced technical support and guidance across a diverse range of plant and equipment in sectors such as agriculture, horticulture, forestry and outdoor power.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* 4 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including English, maths and a science * a basic understanding of information and communication technology (ICT)
app.stnLearn: * environmental, safe working and legal requirements * use of specialist tools and equipment * thermally and chemically joining metals and components * advanced technical and engineering principles of land-based engineering machinery, plant and equipment * service, maintenance and repair principles and practices for complex machinery, plant and equipment * accessing, interpreting and applying technical data * diagnosing faults and verifying machinery
app.stnQual: * Level 3 Diploma in Land-based Engineering * Certificate in Emergency First Aid * Certificate in Abrasive Wheels * Certificate in Fork Lift Truck Handling
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be able to register with the Institution of Agricultural Engineers as an engineering technician (Eng Tech).

app.stnOverview: Installing the infrastructure for the scenic, lighting, sound and audiovisual elements of a live event.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Apprentices must be 18 years old and physically fit. Candidates will usually have:
* at least 3 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and science * basic IT skills
app.stnLearn: * general health and safety * identifying and minimising hazards and risks * selecting, using, storing and maintaining equipment, tools and materials * planning and organisational work methods * rigging skills and techniques * reading and interpreting designs * working at height * team working and communication
app.stnQual:
The apprenticeship includes level 2 assessment for the Professional Lighting and Sound Association’s National Rigging Certificate.
Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Producing tailored clothes that are cut and made to a unique pattern for an individual.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * selecting, using and storing equipment and materials, buying materials and stock control * making efficient and effective use of resources, time and materials * preparing materials and trimmings * identifying and using specific branded cloths * recognising faults in cloth and trimming * tailor specialism: garment construction, finishing and pressing * cutter specialism: preparation of garment parts, identifying and responding to customer requirements
app.stnQual: Employers who recruit candidates without English and maths GCSE grade C (or Functional Skills level 2) or above must ensure that the candidate achieves this level before completion of the apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Supporting the transformation of the way public services are delivered while securing best value for taxpayers’ money.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * the context of procurement, including the commercial lifecycle and the difference between private and public sector procurement * pre-procurement and early market engagement * sourcing and contract agreements * contract and supplier management * category management
app.stnQual: Chartered Institute for Procurement and Supply Diploma in Procurement and Supply Operations (CIPS Level 4)
app.stnReg: On completion of CIPS Level 4 candidates are eligible for diploma level membership of CIPS.

app.stnOverview: Installing and maintaining gas appliances in a domestic or non-domestic setting, advising customers on how appliances work and how to use energy more efficiently.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Applicants will usually have 1 of the following:
* at least 3 GCSEs at grades A to C (or equivalent), including English, maths and a science * relevant experience
Employers will carry out a recognised background check.
app.stnLearn: * theory of combustion and types of burners * flues and ventilation principles * safety checks following gas work on an appliance * range and suitability of appliances and awareness of green technologies * building regulations, water regulations and electrical regulations * emergency procedures * system design, location, controls and flue types for appliances and smart controls
app.stnQual: Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg:
Apprentices must apply to get on the Gas Safe Register for four appliances.
Successful apprentices can apply to register as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) with the Institution of Gas Engineers and Managers (IGEM).

app.stnOverview: Providing picture and sound coverage of sporting, music or other cultural events.
app.stnEntry:
Candidates must have a driving license and be prepared to work away from home. They will also usually have 1 of the following:
* an engineering or technical degree * at least 3 years of substantial experience
app.stnLearn: * technical skills for sound, vision and media management * location-based practice, including rigging cables, working at heights and working on a stage * power management * setting up and using cameras and lighting * networking technologies * radio frequency systems
app.stnQual:
Apprentices will achieve the Postgraduate Diploma in Outside Broadcasting Engineering.
Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths will need to achieve that level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Carrying out beauty treatments for customers.
app.stnEntry: Candidates will take an initial assessment, aptitude test or skills test.
app.stnLearn: * professionalism and customer service * safe working practices * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: beauty and make-up, beauty and spa therapy, nail services
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Leading the installation of complex environmental systems in construction projects.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have achieved 1 of the following (or equivalent):
* a level 4 apprenticeship as a construction technician * EngTech LCIBSE status * an HNC in Building Services Engineering * relevant experience
app.stnLearn: * engineering principles, codes and standards * building services engineering solutions and techniques * project management * people and resources * quality management * commercial and legal awareness * health and safety * sustainability
app.stnQual:
* BEng (Hons) Building Service Engineering or equivalent level 6 building services engineering diploma, mapped to the UK Standard for Professional Engineering Competence (UK-SPEC) for Incorporated Engineer * industry certificates in: site safety, Site Managers’ Safety Training Scheme, Site Environmental Awareness Scheme
Apprentices will also need to demonstrate English at level 3 and maths at level 5.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Using timber products, either on a construction site or in a workshop, creating and installing parts of buildings.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * health and safety * planning and carrying out work to commercial standards of quality and speed * moving, handling and storing resources * interpreting and following verbal and written instructions * selecting and using materials * using and interpreting drawings and specifications to carry out their work * using specialist equipment * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: carpentry, joinery
app.stnQual:
Apprentices must achieve 1 of the following, depending on their specialism: * NVQ Level 2 Diploma in Wood Occupations – Site Carpentry * NVQ Level 2 Diploma in Wood Occupations – Architectural Joinery
Apprentices who don’t have English and maths level 1 qualifications (or equivalent) must achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Helping take clothing from design to manufacture, ensuring that they are launched on time, on cost and to the right quality.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have: * 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and a science, technology or engineering related subject * A levels at grade C or above in a maths-based subject and a science, technology, engineering or another maths-related subject (or 90+ credits in an engineering BTEC at level 3)
app.stnLearn: * producing parts using hand fitting, fabrication and joining techniques * producing drawings using a computer aided design (CAD) system * preparing and using general and specialist machines and equipment * preparing and providing computer numeric control programmes (programmes that control machinery) * using computer software packages to help with engineering activities * producing assemblies using a wide range of materials and techniques * engineering project management, securing resources and managing budgets * implementing, monitoring and evaluating engineering processes
app.stnQual: BSc (Hons) or BEng (Hons) in Engineering
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Using elements manufactured off site, positioning and assembling them in a construction environment.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * health and safety * reading, interpreting and working to drawings, specifications and construction information * assembling, positioning and fixing manufactured elements * using, maintaining and storing specialist tools and equipment * selecting and using different materials * technical skills for installing and removing temporary support and structural elements
app.stnQual: * BSc (Hons) Quantity Surveying or equivalent quantity surveying level 6 diploma, mapped to Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors standards for chartered quantity surveyors * industry certificates in: site safety, Site Managers’ Safety Training Scheme, Site Environmental Awareness Training Scheme
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be able to register as a chartered surveyor with the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors.

app.stnOverview: Managing the financial and legal aspects of construction projects.
app.stnEntry: Candidates will usually have 1 of the following: * 5 GCSEs or equivalent * a level 2 apprenticeship
app.stnLearn: * health and safety * sustainability * construction technology * project management * planning and organising work * monitoring quality * monitoring costs
app.stnQual: HNC in Construction and the Built Environment
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be registered as an associate construction manager with the Chartered Institution of Building.

app.stnOverview: Assisting customers when they buy products or services.
app.stnEntry: None specified.
app.stnLearn: * customer service * supporting the financial performance of the business * marketing principles used in their work * product placement and merchandising * stock control * technical skills, including the role of digital channels * legal and governance requirements
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: None specified.

app.stnOverview: Helping customers make travel arrangements, accommodation and other travel plans.
app.stnEntry: None specified.
app.stnLearn: * world-wide geography and popular holiday destinations * travel information, eg passport and visa requirements * relevant industry systems and processes, eg booking systems * customer service * business compliance and relevant legislation * technology that is relevant to their role
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: The Guild of Travel Management Companies (GTMC) and ABTA (the travel association) have approved the contents of this apprenticeship standard.

app.stnOverview: Carrying out consultations and working with all hair types (from shampooing and conditioning to cutting and styling).
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * shampooing, conditioning and treating the hair and scalp * cutting hair using a range of techniques to create a variety of looks * style and finish hair * barbers: shaving or styling facial hair * hairdressers: perming and relaxing hair
app.stnQual: Apprentices must: * achieve level 1 in English and maths by the end of their apprenticeship * study for level 2 in English and maths after they have finished their apprenticeship
app.stnReg: Not applicable

app.stnOverview: Serving the public food and drink in establishments such as bars and restaurants.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer.
app.stnLearn: * health and safety * customer service * serving food and drinks *making sure tables are clean and tidy * computer skills * dealing with bill payments
app.stnQual: None specified.
app.stnReg: None specified.
